raw_text:
US bank boss hails 'genius' Smith
 
 US Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan has given a speech at a Scottish church in honour of the pioneering economist, Adam Smith.
 
 He delivered the 14th Adam Smith Lecture in Kirkcaldy, Fife. The Adam Smith Lecture celebrates the author of 1776's Wealth of Nations, which became a bible of capitalism. Dr Greenspan was invited by Chancellor Gordon Brown, whose minister father John used to preach at the St Bryce Kirk church. Mr Brown introduced Dr Greenspan to the 400 invited guests as the "the world's greatest economist". Dr Greenspan, 79, who has been in the UK to attend the G7 meeting in London, said the world could never repay the debt of gratitude it owed to Smith, whose genius he compared to that of Mozart.
 
 He said the philosopher was a "towering contributor to the modern world". "Kirkcaldy, the birthplace in 1723 of Adam Smith and, by extension, of modern economics, is also of course, where your chancellor was reared. "I am led to ponder to what extent the chancellor's renowned economic and financial skills are the result of exposure to the subliminal intellect-enhancing emanation in this area." He continued: "Smith reached far beyond the insights of his predecessors to frame a global view of how market economics, just then emerging, worked. "In so doing he supported changes in societal organisation that were to measurably enhance standards of living."
 
 Dr Greenspan said Smith's revolutionary philosophy on human self-interest, laissez-faire economics and competition had been a force for good in the world. "The incredible insights of a handful of intellectuals of the Enlightenment - especially with Smith toiling in the environs of Kirkcaldy - created the modern vision of people free to choose and to act according to their individual self-interest," he said. Following his lecture, Dr Greenspan - who received an honorary knighthood from the Queen at Balmoral in 2002 - was awarded an honorary fellowship of the Royal Society of Edinburgh. He later opened an exhibition dedicated to Smith in the atrium of Fife College of Further and Higher Education. Joyce Johnston, principal of the college, said: "It is very fitting that the world's premier economist delivered this lecture in tribute to the world's first economist." Dr Greenspan - who became chairman of the Federal Reserve for an unprecedented fifth term in June 2004 - will step down in January next year. He has served under Presidents George W Bush, Bill Clinton, George Bush, and Ronald Reagan. He was also chairman of the council of economic advisors to Gerald Ford.
llama3.2:1b: US bank boss Alan Greenspan delivered a speech at a Scottish church in honor of Adam Smith, praising his "genius" and contributions to modern economics.
The lecture celebrated Smith's book "The Wealth of Nations," which became a foundational text for capitalism.
Greenspan compared Smith's ideas to those of Mozart, saying that the world could never repay his debt of gratitude.
He praised Smith's work on human self-interest, laissez-faire economics, and competition, which he said had improved standards of living worldwide.
llama3.2:3b: US Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan delivers the 14th Adam Smith Lecture at a Scottish church, praising economist Adam Smith as "genius" and comparing his impact to Mozart's.
Greenspan calls Smith a "towering contributor" who framed global market economics and supported changes in societal organisation that enhanced standards of living.
gemma2:2b: Alan Greenspan honored Adam Smith by delivering a lecture at a Scottish church.
Greenspan praised Smith's impact on capitalism and modern economics, calling him a "genius" comparable to Mozart.
He highlighted Smith's contribution to shaping market economics and enhancing living standards.
Greenspan received an honorary fellowship from the Royal Society of Edinburgh following his lecture.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Adam Smith: The world's first economist and revolutionary thinker who challenged traditional economic thinking with his ideas about human self-interest, laissez-faire economics, and competition, which he believed could improve societal standards of living.
Dr Greenspan described him as a "towering contributor to the modern world" and said he reached beyond the insights of his predecessors in framing a global view of market economics.
He was awarded an honorary knighthood from the Queen at Balmoral in 2002 for his revolutionary ideas on human self-interest, laissez-faire economics, and competition.
He became chairman of the Federal Reserve for an unprecedented fifth term in June 2004.
Dr Greenspan will step down in January next year.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Alan Greenspan, US Federal Reserve chairman, delivers 14th Adam Smith Lecture at a Scottish church honoring pioneer economist Adam Smith.
Smith is praised for his genius compared to Mozart, revolutionizing modern economics and supporting societal changes that improved living standards.
qwen2.5:3b: US Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan delivered the 14th Adam Smith Lecture at a Scottish church in honor of economist Adam Smith, author of "Wealth of Nations."
Greenspan praised Smith's genius, comparing him to Mozart and emphasizing Smith’s revolutionary philosophy on human self-interest, laissez-faire economics, and competition.
The lecture highlighted Smith's influence in creating the modern vision of free markets enhancing living standards.
Greenspan was awarded an honorary fellowship by the Royal Society of Edinburgh post-lecture and will step down as Federal Reserve Chairman next January.

During his visit, he compared Smith's genius with that of Mozart and recalled how Smith's philosophy influenced changes in societal organization.

The philosopher-economist, Adam Smith, whose work is credited with advancing modern economic thought, was born in Kirkcaldy, Fife, which is also known as the birthplace of his "towersing contribution" to the modern world.
Dr Greenspan was awarded an honorary fellowship of the Royal Society of Edinburgh, and his lecture honoured Smith's legacy in influencing modern economic thought.

stablelm2:1.6b: US Fed Chairman Alan Greenspan delivered a speech at the Adam Smith Lecture in honor of pioneering economist Adam Smith.

granite3.1-dense:2b: US Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan delivered the 14th Adam Smith Lecture in Kirkcaldy, Scotland, honoring the economist who authored "Wealth of Nations."
Invited by then-Chancellor Gordon Brown, Dr. Greenspan was introduced as the world's greatest economist by Brown, whose father once preached at the venue.
The speech highlighted Smith's genius, comparing it to Mozart's, and praised his global contributions to modern economics.
Dr. Greenspan emphasized Smith's role in shaping free-market principles, human self-interest, laissez-faire economics, and competition as forces for societal improvement.
Post-lecture, he received an honorary fellowship from the Royal Society of Edinburgh and opened a Smith tribute exhibition at Fife College.
Dr. Greenspan, who will step down in 2014 after an unprecedented fifth term as Fed chairman, has served under five US presidents and held various economic advisory roles.
